articles.headline: G.M. Says Its Driverless Car Could Be in Fleets by Next Year
articles.snippet: Once federal and state agencies grant approval, the electric vehicle will be ready for production on a standard assembly line, the automaker said.
articles.abstract: Once federal and state agencies grant approval, the electric vehicle will be ready for production on a standard assembly line, the automaker said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The advent of self-driving cars, the subject of so much fanfare over the last few years from automakers and technology companies, may be just around the corner — at least according to General Motors.

articles.headline: With a Tax Deduction Gone, Is Home Equity a Smart Way to Pay for College?
articles.snippet: The new tax law removes the ability to deduct interest paid on home equity loans. Will schools ask less of families, and should parents even use the loans to pay for school?
articles.abstract: The new tax law removes the ability to deduct interest paid on home equity loans. Will schools ask less of families, and should parents even use the loans to pay for school?
articles.lead_paragraph: For parents facing the prospect of six-figure college bills, every bit of savings and every last tax break helps.

articles.headline: Trump’s Demand to Rewrite Iran Deal Tests a Weakened Diplomatic Corps
articles.snippet: The Trump administration is being forced to rethink strategies that were driven largely by military considerations.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration is being forced to rethink strategies that were driven largely by military considerations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, by demanding on Friday that European allies agree to rewrite the Iran nuclear deal within 120 days or he will kill it, set himself a diplomatic challenge that would be formidable even for an administration with a deep bench of experienced negotiators.

articles.headline: Jeff Bezos, Mr. Amazon, Steps Out
articles.snippet: Mr. Bezos is the world’s richest person and can afford virtually any luxury. But obscurity is no longer among them.
articles.abstract: Mr. Bezos is the world’s richest person and can afford virtually any luxury. But obscurity is no longer among them.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Jeff Bezos rubbed elbows last weekend with Halle Berry, Chris Hemsworth and other Hollywood celebrities at an after-party for the Golden Globes. In December, he walked the red carpet, along with Meryl Streep and Tom Hanks, at a screening of “The Post” in Washington.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Nellie Bowles

articles.headline: A President Who Fans, Rather Than Douses, the Nation’s Racial Fires
articles.snippet: After his latest incendiary comments, the president’s critics say there is no doubt he is a racist. The White House calls such suggestions “insulting.”
articles.abstract: After his latest incendiary comments, the president’s critics say there is no doubt he is a racist. The White House calls such suggestions “insulting.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As he signed a proclamation marking the holiday next week honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., President Trump on Friday recalled the civil rights leader’s message that “no matter what the color of our skin or the place of our birth, we are created equal by God.”

articles.headline: The Difficulties With Facebook’s News Feed Overhaul
articles.snippet: Facebook faces complex questions over its prioritization of “meaningful” content in the News Feed, including whether people want that kind of content in the first place.
articles.abstract: Facebook faces complex questions over its prioritization of “meaningful” content in the News Feed, including whether people want that kind of content in the first place.
articles.lead_paragraph: Imagine you’re a cookie mogul. You figured out a way to make lots of money by giving away delicious cookies for free, and in less than a decade, you created a global cookie behemoth.

articles.headline: Porn Star Was Reportedly Paid to Stay Quiet About Trump
articles.snippet: The reported $130,000 payment was made shortly before the election. Mr. Trump “vehemently denies” the encounter happened, his lawyer said.
articles.abstract: The reported $130,000 payment was made shortly before the election. Mr. Trump “vehemently denies” the encounter happened, his lawyer said.
articles.lead_paragraph: A lawyer for President Trump orchestrated a $130,000 payment to a pornographic film actress in October 2016 to prevent her from going public with claims of a consensual sexual encounter with Mr. Trump, The Wall Street Journal reported on Friday.
articles.byline: By Megan Twohey and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Inside Uber’s $100,000 Payment to a Hacker, and the Fallout
articles.snippet: How Uber grappled with a 2016 hack is under scrutiny and has cast a chill over how other companies deal with security threats.
articles.abstract: How Uber grappled with a 2016 hack is under scrutiny and has cast a chill over how other companies deal with security threats.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — “Hello Joe,” read the November 2016 email from someone identifying himself as “John Doughs.” “I have found a major vulnerability in Uber.”
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: The Marriage Ended. The Company Thrived.
articles.snippet: How Brad Black and Susan Griffin-Black built EO Products into an all-natural skin care juggernaut despite getting a divorce along the way.
articles.abstract: How Brad Black and Susan Griffin-Black built EO Products into an all-natural skin care juggernaut despite getting a divorce along the way.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN RAFAEL, CALIF. — It is a bright September day and I am standing in a 45,000-square-foot space in Marin County that was once the “Star Wars” studio of George Lucas and is now the home of EO Products. It is hard to imagine a high-tech film studio being converted into the production facility for an organic cosmetics company — one that features products like a mint-and-coconut soap and sulfate-free shampoos and conditioners. There is something implausible about the optics of it, if nothing else. Then again, there is something implausible about EO Products itself, beginning with its homegrown origins and the way that, more than two decades later, the company is run by Brad Black and Susan Griffin-Black, the couple who head it.

articles.headline: As Labor Pool Shrinks, Prison Time Is Less of a Hiring Hurdle
articles.snippet: A shortage of candidates is providing opportunities to people long shunned by employers and is forcing recruiters to consider new approaches to hiring.
articles.abstract: A shortage of candidates is providing opportunities to people long shunned by employers and is forcing recruiters to consider new approaches to hiring.
articles.lead_paragraph: A rapidly tightening labor market is forcing companies across the country to consider workers they once would have turned away. That is providing opportunities to people who have long faced barriers to employment, such as criminal records, disabilities or prolonged bouts of joblessness.

articles.headline: Buying a Piece of Bob Marley’s Song Catalog, and His Enduring Legacy
articles.snippet: Primary Wave, a boutique New York company that aggressively markets “icons and legends”, bought the rights to Marley’s songs in a $50 million deal.
articles.abstract: Primary Wave, a boutique New York company that aggressively markets “icons and legends”, bought the rights to Marley’s songs in a $50 million deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Chris Blackwell, the founder of Island Records, first met a journeyman musician named Bob Marley in 1972, he had a feeling that the young man might find success.

articles.headline: In Trump’s Immigration Remarks, Echoes of a Century-Old Racial Ranking
articles.snippet: The president’s vulgar comments about certain countries harken back to complaints about “undesirable nationals” that led to severe restrictions in 1924.
articles.abstract: The president’s vulgar comments about certain countries harken back to complaints about “undesirable nationals” that led to severe restrictions in 1924.
articles.lead_paragraph: The argument was genteel, the tone judicious, the meaning plain: America, wrote the senator leading Congress’s push for immigration reform in 1924, was beginning to “smart under the irritation” of immigrants who “speak a foreign language and live a foreign life.”

articles.headline: Hawaii Panics After Alert About Incoming Missile Is Sent in Error
articles.snippet: The alert appeared on cellphones warning people to “seek immediate shelter,” and said, “This is not a drill.” The authorities said it was a false alarm.
articles.abstract: The alert appeared on cellphones warning people to “seek immediate shelter,” and said, “This is not a drill.” The authorities said it was a false alarm.
articles.lead_paragraph: An early-morning emergency alert mistakenly warning of an incoming ballistic missile attack was dispatched to cellphones across Hawaii on Saturday, setting off widespread panic in a state that was already on edge because of escalating tensions between the United States and North Korea.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, David E. Sanger and Johanna Barr

articles.headline: In Some Countries, Facebook’s Fiddling Has Magnified Fake News
articles.snippet: Last fall, the online giant altered what people in six nations see. Established news sites said their web traffic declined, adding that more bogus stories were shared instead.
articles.abstract: Last fall, the online giant altered what people in six nations see. Established news sites said their web traffic declined, adding that more bogus stories were shared instead.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One morning in October, the editors of Página Siete, Bolivia’s third-largest news site, noticed that traffic to their outlet coming from Facebook was plummeting.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel, Nicholas Casey and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: ‘I’m Running,’ Romney Says Privately, but as a Trump Friend or Foe?
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney’s expected return to politics in a run to be the next senator from Utah has set off a debate over whether he should actively counter President Trump.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney’s expected return to politics in a run to be the next senator from Utah has set off a debate over whether he should actively counter President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — A few days after Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah announced that he would conclude his tenure after serving 42 years in office, the state’s governor, Gary Herbert, was growing anxious about whether Mitt Romney would run for the seat.

articles.headline: Hopes Dim for DACA Deal as Lawmakers Battle Over Trump’s Immigration Remarks
articles.snippet: Senator David Perdue, who attended the White House meeting, said Senator Richard J. Durbin’s account of President Trump’s language was a “gross misrepresentation.”
articles.abstract: Senator David Perdue, who attended the White House meeting, said Senator Richard J. Durbin’s account of President Trump’s language was a “gross misrepresentation.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After three days of denunciations from around the world, President Trump declared that he is “not a racist” on Sunday, even as the uproar over his vulgar remarks on immigration overshadowed critical issues facing the capital, including efforts to protect young undocumented immigrants and avert a government shutdown.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan, Noah Weiland and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Big Bets on A.I. Open a New Frontier for Chip Start-Ups, Too
articles.snippet: Forty-five young companies are building processors just for artificial intelligence. At least five have raised more than $100 million from investors.
articles.abstract: Forty-five young companies are building processors just for artificial intelligence. At least five have raised more than $100 million from investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, tech industry financiers showed little interest in start-up companies that made computer chips.

articles.headline: Detroit Auto Show May Be Celebrating an Era About to End
articles.snippet: Three years of record sales mask signs that harder times lie ahead: bigger incentives, more fleet purchases and higher used-car values.
articles.abstract: Three years of record sales mask signs that harder times lie ahead: bigger incentives, more fleet purchases and higher used-car values.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Automakers have reason to celebrate as they gather this week at the Detroit auto show to unveil the new range of brawny trucks, high-tech cars and rugged sport-utility vehicles that will arrive in showrooms in the months ahead.

articles.headline: In Iran, Protester ‘Suicides’ Stir Anger and Calls for Accountability
articles.snippet: A willingness by members of Iran’s mainstream society to dispute official versions of protester deaths suggest that the fallout may be just beginning.
articles.abstract: A willingness by members of Iran’s mainstream society to dispute official versions of protester deaths suggest that the fallout may be just beginning.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Two of the detained young men killed themselves, and another was a terrorist who died in a clash with security forces, Iran’s government officials have declared with finality. But in an extraordinary display of audacity, many Iranians, including a number of lawmakers and a top entertainment star, have assailed such conclusions.

articles.headline: Military Quietly Prepares for a Last Resort: War With North Korea
articles.snippet: It’s normal for American commanders to draw up combat plans. But recent exercises signal that the military wants to be ready for options on the Korean Peninsula.
articles.abstract: It’s normal for American commanders to draw up combat plans. But recent exercises signal that the military wants to be ready for options on the Korean Peninsula.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Across the military, officers and troops are quietly preparing for a war they hope will not come.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and John Ismay

articles.headline: In Montecito, Enclave of Wealth and Fame, Unimagined Tragedy
articles.snippet: Mudslides left the coastal community of Montecito, Calif., in ruins, and rescuers were racing against time on Sunday to find four people still missing.
articles.abstract: Mudslides left the coastal community of Montecito, Calif., in ruins, and rescuers were racing against time on Sunday to find four people still missing.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTECITO, Calif. — A green, military-style Humvee drove along the shore here, the beach on one side, the shuttered Four Seasons Hotel on the other. Up in the hillsides, a no-go zone for civilians, multimillion-dollar mansions are flooded with mud, and cars, tossed about like playthings, are now just hunks of twisted metal, jammed against trees.
